channel.title: NYT > Home Page
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: New Trump Deportation Rules Allow Far More Expulsions
item.media:description: Mexicans deported from the U.S. walked to a repatriation center in Tijuana in June 2016.
item.description: The rules authorize expelling undocumented immigrants who have committed even minor offenses, and they make it easier to deport people immediately.
item.dc:creator: RON NIXON and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Trump Speaks Out Against Anti-Semitism
item.description: He made the comments after drawing criticism in recent days for failing to condemn the rise in anti-Jewish threats and actions.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.category: National Museum of African American History and Culture

item.title: Lawyers Take On Trump’s Travel Ban
item.description: The judiciary is the new front line: A group of lawyers scramble to get their clients into the country, while preparing a legal challenge to Trump’s immigration ban.

item.title: Riots Break Out in Stockholm Suburb, Drawing Attention to Trump’s Remarks
item.media:description: Burned cars on Tuesday in Rinkeby, a northwestern Stockholm suburb predominantly inhabited by immigrants. About 20 to 30 masked men threw stones and other objects at police officers in Rinkeby after the police arrested a man on suspicion of dealing drugs.
item.description: The clash between the police and residents came two days after President Trump’s provocative claims about migration and crime in the country.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON

item.title: White House Memo: From an Anchor’s Lips to Trump’s Ears to Sweden’s Disbelief
item.media:description: A group of refugees walking on a highway in Denmark toward Sweden in 2015. Statistics in Sweden found no appreciable increase in crimes from 2015, when the country processed a record 163,000 asylum applications, to 2016.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: A diplomatic dispute with Sweden illustrates the unusual approach the president takes to foreign policy, as well as the influence that television can have on his thinking.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Europe Combats a New Foe of Political Stability: Fake News
item.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, center, a French presidential candidate, in southern France on Friday. The head of his party said Mr. Macron had been targeted by Russian news channels.
item.description: The rise of sophisticated hacks and a torrent of fake news coincide with angry populist movements across the Continent, and officials are nervous.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT and MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Town Hall Briefing: Congressional Town Hall: Of Tums, Death Panels and ‘Shut Your Hole’
item.media:description: Senator Charles E. Grassley at a town hall meeting in Iowa Falls, Iowa, on Tuesday. He addressed a standing-room-only crowd.
item.media:credit: Scott Morgan for The New York Times
item.description: Several Republicans will be hearing from constituents on Tuesday, and reporters for The New York Times will be there to gauge the sentiment.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS KAPLAN, TRIP GABRIEL and LIZETTE ALVAREZ
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: For-Profit Schools, an Obama Target, See New Day Under Trump
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump at the announcement of the establishment of Trump University in 2005. As president-elect, he paid $25 million to settle three lawsuits against the now-defunct institution.
item.description: The Education Department, whose scrutiny has led hundreds of campuses to close, is now led by Betsy DeVos, who has investments in the industry.
item.dc:creator: PATRICIA COHEN

item.title: Protesters Ready for Trump’s First Visit to New York as President
item.media:description: Congregation Beth Elohim in Brooklyn was filled on Feb. 6 for an evening of strategizing against President Trump.
item.media:credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
item.description: The president has not set foot in the city since his inauguration, puzzling and emboldening some protesters in his hometown.
item.dc:creator: SARAH MASLIN NIR

item.title: Milo Yiannopoulos’s Pedophilia Comments Cost Him CPAC Role and Book Deal
item.media:description: Milo Yiannopoulos last month in Boulder, Colo. The Conservative Political Action Conference rescinded its invitation for him to speak to the group after his comments about pedophilia.
item.media:credit: Jeremy Papasso/Daily Camera, via Associated Press
item.description: The publication of a video in which the contentious Breitbart News editor condoned sexual relations with boys seemed to be more than conference organizers could tolerate.
item.dc:creator: JEREMY W. PETERS, ALEXANDRA ALTER and MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM

item.title: Unease Spreads in Atlanta as a City Contracting Scandal Brews
item.media:description: Mayor Kasim Reed of Atlanta delivering his State of the City address this month. An investigation into charges of bribery involving city contracts has prompted the mayor to defend his legacy.
item.media:credit: Branden Camp/Atlanta Journal-Constitution, via Associated Press
item.description: A brick thrown through a window, dead rodents left on steps and a threat to a contractor have become symbols of a federal inquiry into bribery charges.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD FAUSSET

item.title: A Surprising Salve for New York’s Beleaguered Cities: Refugees
item.media:description: In early February a man wearing a keffiyeh walked past a mural that recalls a less diverse past in Buffalo. The self-described “City of Good Neighbors” has received more than 10,000 refugees over the last decade.
item.media:credit: Nathaniel Brooks for The New York Times
item.description: Communities across upstate New York say an influx of refugees has helped alleviate decades-long struggles with dwindling populations and opportunities.
item.dc:creator: JESSE McKINLEY

item.title: Firsthand Account: The Assassination of Malcolm X
item.description: The civil rights leader Malcolm X was killed Feb. 21, 1965, at a rally in New York City. Hear from a witness and visit the site of the assassination — in the past, present and in 360 video.

item.title: California Today: California Today: Lawmakers With Little in Common, Except a Name
item.media:description: Representative Kevin McCarthy of California, the majority leader, at his office in the U.S. Capitol.
item.description: Tuesday: Name confusion vexes a California representative and assemblyman, a Whittier police officer is killed, and clam digging in Humboldt Bay.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Your Daily Mini Crossword
item.description: Solve a bite-size crossword in just a few minutes.

item.title: Travel Tips: How to Have a Better Flight
item.description: A longtime flight attendant says that politeness helps improve a trip, as does bringing your own food for the ride.
item.dc:creator: SHIVANI VORA

item.title: Trying to Stanch Trinidad’s Flow of Young Recruits to ISIS
item.media:description: Yasin Abu Bakr, second from right, speaking with other Muslims at his mosque in Port of Spain, Trinidad and Tobago.
item.media:credit: Federico Rios Escobar for The New York Times
item.description: Officials in Trinidad and Tobago are scrambling to close a pipeline that has sent a steady stream of Muslims to Syria to take up arms for the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Goalie Eats Pie and Loses His Job, While Bettors’ Wallets Fatten
item.media:description: Sutton’s backup goalkeeper, Wayne Shaw, eats a pie during the match against Arsenal on Monday.
item.description: The backup goalkeeper for Sutton, Wayne Shaw, said he knew about a bet on whether he’d have a pie during the match and had eaten because of it.
item.dc:creator: VICTOR MATHER

item.title: Out There: Cosmos Controversy: The Universe Is Expanding, but How Fast?
item.media:description: A Hubble Space Telescope image of a group of interacting galaxies called Arp 273.
item.description: A small discrepancy in the value of a long-sought number has fostered a debate about just how well we know the cosmos.
item.dc:creator: DENNIS OVERBYE

item.title: Afghanistan Police Surround Vice President’s House
item.media:description: Abdul Rashid Dostum, an Afghan vice president, in 2014. On Tuesday, over 100 police officers and soldiers surrounded his Kabul compound in an apparent effort to arrest nine of of his aides.
item.description: Soldiers and police officers appeared to be trying to arrest nine aides to Vice President Abdul Rashid Dostum accused of kidnapping a political rival.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: Bodies of 74 Migrants Wash Up on Libyan Coast
item.media:description: Red Crescent workers collected the bodies of migrants on Monday from a beach near the town of Zawiya, Libya.
item.description: The victims were believed to have come from a shipwrecked boat that was found along the shore, an ominous sign before the high season for crossings to Europe.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Elor Azaria, Israeli Soldier Who Killed Wounded Assailant, Gets 18 Months in Prison
item.media:description: Sgt. Elor Azaria, center, with his mother in a military courtroom in Tel Aviv on Tuesday before he received an 18-month sentence for manslaughter.
item.description: The sergeant shot an incapacitated Palestinian lying on his back, a case that has divided Israelis and prompted calls for a pardon.
item.dc:creator: IAN FISHER

item.title: The Interpreter
item.description: The Interpreter brings sharp insight and context to the major news stories of the week. Sign up to get it by email.

item.title: Vatican and Rome’s Jewish Museum Team Up for Menorah Exhibit
item.media:description: A bas-relief showing a menorah was displayed at a news conference on Monday announcing a joint exhibition by the Vatican Museums and Rome’s Jewish Museum.
item.description: The collaboration, centered on a famous candelabrum that has been missing for centuries, is being hailed as “a historic event.”
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: The Businessman Behind Cool British Fashion Brands
item.media:description: Peter Dubens, the co-founder and managing partner of Oakley Capital Private Equity, is the investor behind Alexa Chung’s fashion label.
item.description: Peter Dubens, co-founder of Oakley Capital, has financed both Alexa Chung and Bella Freud.
item.dc:creator: LAUREN INDVIK

item.title: A.S. Monaco: From Billionaire’s Plaything to Soccer Prodigies’ Hub
item.media:description: Vadim Vasilyev, the vice president of A.S. Monaco, remembers the “tough” night in 2015 when he explained to fans the club’s shift away from signing star players.
item.media:credit: France Keyser for The New York Times
item.description: Financial fair-play rules forced a change in club strategy, one that has had some unexpectedly happy results.
item.dc:creator: RORY SMITH

item.title: Sinosphere: Scammers in China Fake Road Injuries, but Cameras Capture the Truth
item.description: Fraudsters are throwing themselves in front of cars or buses to extort money from motorists, but the results are often unconvincing.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Eleven Madison Park Plans a Makeover and a Summer Pop-Up
item.media:description: Like many New Yorkers, the staff and operations of Eleven Madison Park will spend this summer in the Hamptons. They will take over the restaurant Moby’s, opening it in late June as EMP Summer House.
item.media:credit: Daniel Gonzalez for The New York Times
item.description: The top-rated Manhattan restaurant will close for three months of renovation and open a more casual version in the Hamptons.
item.dc:creator: FLORENCE FABRICANT

item.title: Dick Bruna, Author of Miffy Books, Is Dead at 89
item.media:description: Dick Bruna in 2005 at the opening of an exhibition devoted to his Miffy books in The Hague.
item.media:credit: Inge Van Mill/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The Dutch writer and illustrator was known for children’s books depicting a sparely drawn round white rabbit who gained a worldwide following.
item.dc:creator: NINA SIEGAL

item.title: Shared: A Balm When You’re Expecting: Sometimes Pot Does the Trick
item.media:description: Jane, who used pot to quell her nausea during her third pregnancy, with her daughter in New York
item.media:credit: Nancie Battaglia for The New York Times
item.description: Five women describe why they used marijuana while pregnant, and how they assessed the risks and benefits before making that choice.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE SAINT LOUIS

item.title: The Fix: The Convertible, Tiny Apartment
item.media:description: A Murphy bed and flanking closets disappear into the living room walls when not in use.
item.media:credit: Linda Jaquez for The New York Times
item.description: A 400-square-foot studio is remade into a space that can be constantly transformed.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE HIGGINS

item.title: Personal Health: The Worst That Could Happen? Going Blind, People Say
item.description: When eyesight fails, some people become socially disengaged, leading to isolation and loneliness.
item.dc:creator: JANE E. BRODY
